Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports funding to work on a new search algorithm for moving faint objects and apply it to existing datasets in the Sloan Digital Sky Survey II (SDSS-II) and Dark Energy Survey (DES) in order to discover new objects in our solar system. The new design, called Kernel-Based Moving Object Detection (KB-MOD) will speed computations by a factor of a hundred, and use a probabilistic framework to help the user make better decisions about when a new object has been discovered, and when the limitations are reached and one should stop looking. The improved sensitivity will make it possible to discover smaller and more distant (and hence, fainter) outer solar system objects, which will help complete the census of the outer solar system, including the Kuiper Belt region, beyond Neptune. The PI and his team will train and mentor students from traditionally underrepresented groups through the University of Washington's Pre-Major in Astronomy Program (Pre-MAP), which targets students who have not yet declared a major and integrates them into the research environment so that they will be more likely to major in science.

The scope of the proposal includes developing a probabilistic, image-based analysis infrastructure, and build and implement scalable methods to access the data using trajectories from a wide range of potential solar system orbits. The work will also integrate science data from the SDSS and DES into the LSST Data Management environment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Studying the orbits of asteroids in the outer parts of our Solar System provides a window into the early history of the Solar System. Current models suggest that all the giant planets formed well-interior to 20 AU and migrated outwards due to interactions with planetesimals. Detailed studies of the dynamical properties of these asteroid populations (often referred to as Trans-Neptunian Objects or TNOs) can directly test theories for the formation of our Solar System including the smooth migration of Neptune, a stellar flyby, or rogue planetary embryos. Our work, developing the KBMOD framework, introduces new methods for searching for and finding faint, slow moving asteroids within collections of astronomical images. Designed to work on GPUs, KBMOD can search over 10,000,000,000 candidate trajectories within a minute; enabling the discovery of asteroids below the detection limit of any one image or observation. We demonstrated KBMOD on existing data sets discovering 39 new TNOS in an area covering a 150 sq degrees of the sky. Upcoming surveys such as the Legacy Survey of Space and Time (LSST) will survey over 18,000 square degrees of the sky 825 times over a period of 10 years. LSST plans to detect Solar System objects from individual images and expects to detect about 40,000 TNOs (a 20-fold increase over the number currently known). Applying techniques such as those developed for KBMOD to just three months of LSST data would increase the number of TNOs detected by LSST by a factor of 8.0. If we could coadd a year of LSST data, this increases over to 520,000 new TNOs detected. It might even be possible to detect small planetary bodies out to the Outer Oort Cloud with perihelion near 400 AU, and aphelion beyond. The algorithms and tools created through this work have been used in workshops and tutorials to introduce machine learning techniques to the astronomical community and the development of image processing applications led to a publication on the comparison of image analysis frameworks used across a broad range of scientific fields.
